title: Understanding SQL JOINs
text: In SQL, a JOIN clause is used to combine rows from two or more tables, based on a related column between them.

title: Types of JOINs
text: There are several types of JOINs in SQL, including INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL OUTER JOIN. Each type serves a different purpose in combining data from tables.

hintAnswer: It specifies the condition for joining tables, usually by matching columns.
title: Using the ON Clause
text: What is the purpose of the ON clause in a SQL JOIN statement?
choices: It specifies the condition for joining tables, usually by matching columns.
It limits the number of rows returned.
It defines the order of the output columns.

title: Understanding the USING Clause
text: The USING clause is used in SQL JOINs to specify the column(s) that should be used for matching records between tables when the column names are the same in both tables.

hintAnswer: It specifies the column(s) that should be used for matching records between tables.
title: Purpose of the USING Clause
text: What is the purpose of the USING clause in a SQL JOIN statement?
choices: It defines the order of the output columns.
It specifies the column(s) that should be used for matching records between tables.
It limits the number of rows returned.
